title: 115_hr3179
content: The Act is named the "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act". It includes a requirement for cost-benefit analysis for certain prudential regulations. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates that Federal banking agencies cannot impose stricter prudential regulations than international standards without publishing a rationale and cost-benefit analysis for public comment. This includes assessing impacts on credit availability, pricing, and market liquidity. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" prohibits Federal banking agencies from implementing stricter prudential regulations based on international standards without first publishing a rationale and cost-benefit analysis for public comment. This includes evaluating impacts on market liquidity, competitiveness of institutions, employment, economic growth, and monetary policy execution. Additionally, the agency must propose to repeal or amend any superseded prudential regulations before adopting new international standards. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" requires Federal banking agencies to provide a rationale and cost-benefit analysis for public comment before implementing stricter prudential regulations based on international standards. If the agency does not propose to repeal or amend superseded regulations, they must provide a comprehensive analysis of the costs and benefits. Additionally, a lookback requirement applies to final rules issued after January 1, 2007, that are more stringent than corresponding international standards. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates Federal banking agencies to report to Congress within 180 days on prudential regulations stricter than international standards or those superseding previous regulations. Definitions for "appropriate Federal banking agency" and "banking organization" are provided in the Act. The term "banking organization" refers to a depository institution or a depository institution holding company as defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The term "corresponding international prudential standard" pertains to an international standard that serves as the basis for prudential regulations. The term "prudential regulation" encompasses rules related to capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements. The term "prudential regulation" refers to rules regarding capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements, including minimum requirements for banking organizations' capital, debt, and liquid assets. It also includes regulations based on international standards. An international standard is a prudential regulation based on international prudential standards set by institutions like the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board. These standards cover capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. The term "superseded prudential regulation" refers to a regulation that addresses similar risks or achieves the same goals as an international standard.
